{"comments": {"id": 27707, "count": 12, "talk_id": 8786}, "threadId": 27707, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "8786", "description": "Think we're winning the battle against HIV? Maybe not, as the next wave of drug-resistant viruses arrives. In an eye-opening talk, TED Fellow Edsel Salvana describes the aggressive HIV subtype AE that's currently plaguing his home of the Philippines -- and warns us about what might become a global epidemic.", "event": "TEDGlobal 2017", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Edsel Salvaña: The dangerous evolution of HIV", "slug": "edsel_salvana_the_dangerous_evolution_of_hiv", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "3575", "slug": "edsel_salvana", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Edsel", "lastname": "Salvaña", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Infectious disease specialist, molecular epidemiologist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/8b715c9ec4fc92240725a86e8bb63bf4c9e01194_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "TED Fellow Edsel Salvaña studies the genetics of HIV, and he worries that we are just a few mutations away from the next deadly pandemic.", "whylisten": "

Dr. Edsel Salvaña discovered that the driving force behind a new AIDS epidemic in the Philippines is the entry and spread of a deadlier strain of HIV -- a situation that can easily occur anywhere in the world.

Salvaña is an infectious disease specialist, molecular epidemiologist and is the director of the Institute of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology at the National Institutes of Health at the University of the Philippines in Manila. He is using next-generation sequencing and other cutting-edge genetic tools to study HIV viral diversity and superinfection. He is looking at how HIV develops drug resistance to better understand why his country suddenly has the fastest growing HIV epidemic in Asia; and why HIV treatment that works well in developed countries is failing on emerging HIV strains in the Philippines and resource-limited settings. He trains doctors in infectious diseases, and supervises the care of several thousand HIV patients at the Philippine General Hospital. He has been a national force in the formulation of HIV treatment guidelines, campaigning against stigma, and raising awareness.

Salvaña's advocacy work has been featured in Science, and he has been recognized with numerous national and international awards including the "Ten Outstanding Young Persons of the World" from JCI International and the Young Physician Leader Award from the Interacademy Medical Panel of the World Academy of Sciences. He was named a TED Fellow in 2017.

Beyrer and Pozniak highlight the disturbing trend in increasing HIV drug resistance globally. They particularly worry that cuts to global health programs will devastate previous gains against HIV and we will lose control of the epidemic anew.", "note": "Beyrer C, Pozniak A. *The New England Journal of Medicine*, 2017", "link_url": "http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMp1710608#t=article", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*And the Band Played On: Politics, People, and the AIDS Epidemic*", "blurb": "A gripping chronicle of the early days of the AIDS epidemic in the 1980s, as the scientific community grappled with identifying and treating the virus, and people living with HIV suffered severe stigma and faced death on a daily basis. A [movie](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106273/) based on the book has been made and is highly recommended as well, lest we forget what HIV really looks like without the life-saving treatment that is easily taken for granted.", "note": "Randy Shilts St. Martin’s Press, 1987", "link_url": "", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}]}]}, "more_resources": [], "corrections": [], "has_citations": true, "take_action": [{"status": "approved", "blurb": "**Support** funding for continuing research on HIV treatment, prevention, and cure. Recent cuts in local and international HIV funding are threatening efforts to control and eliminate HIV worldwide. Get your government and other funding agencies to invest in programs towards elimination of the HIV and AIDS epidemic.", "link_url": "http://foreignpolicy.com/2017/12/01/proposed-u-s-cuts-to-aids-funding-could-cause-millions-of-deaths-report-world-aids-day-hiv-global-health-pepfar-state-department-trump-one-campaign/", "visible_url": "foreignpolicy.com", "start_at": null, "end_at": null, "published": true, "eyebrow": null, "type": "take_action", "verb": "participate"}, {"status": "approved", "blurb": "**Practice** safe and responsible sex, and don't share needles. Transmission of drug-resistant HIV is on the rise. Even those already infected with HIV can contract drug-resistant HIV from a sexual partner or from sharing needles. If you are already infected, take your medicines regularly so that resistance doesn't develop.", "link_url": "https://www.avert.org/hiv-transmission-prevention", "visible_url": "avert.org", "start_at": null, "end_at": null, "published": true, "eyebrow": null, "type": "take_action", "verb": "learn"}], "curator_approved": true, "description": "Think we're winning the battle against HIV? "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/8b715c9ec4fc92240725a86e8bb63bf4c9e01194_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "TED Fellow Edsel Salvaña studies the genetics of HIV, and he worries that we are just a few mutations away from the next deadly pandemic.", "whylisten": "

Dr. Edsel Salvaña discovered that the driving force behind a new AIDS epidemic in the Philippines is the entry and spread of a deadlier strain of HIV -- a situation that can easily occur anywhere in the world.

Salvaña is an infectious disease specialist, molecular epidemiologist and is the director of the Institute of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology at the National Institutes of Health at the University of the Philippines in Manila. He is using next-generation sequencing and other cutting-edge genetic tools to study HIV viral diversity and superinfection. He is looking at how HIV develops drug resistance to better understand why his country suddenly has the fastest growing HIV epidemic in Asia; and why HIV treatment that works well in developed countries is failing on emerging HIV strains in the Philippines and resource-limited settings. He trains doctors in infectious diseases, and supervises the care of several thousand HIV patients at the Philippine General Hospital. He has been a national force in the formulation of HIV treatment guidelines, campaigning against stigma, and raising awareness.

Salvaña's advocacy work has been featured in Science, and he has been recognized with numerous national and international awards including the "Ten Outstanding Young Persons of the World" from JCI International and the Young Physician Leader Award from the Interacademy Medical Panel of the World Academy of Sciences. He was named a TED Fellow in 2017.

"}], "speaker_name": "Edsel Salvaña", "tags": ["TED Fellows", "science", "medical research", "virus", "HIV"], "title": "The dangerous evolution of HIV", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 1314020}]}
author: Edsel_Salvaña;
title: The dangerous evolution of HIV

It is also the epicenter of one of the fastest growing HIV epidemics in the world. On the surface, it seems as if we are just a late bloomer. However, the reasons for our current epidemic are much more complicated and may foreshadow a global resurgence of HIV. While overall new cases of HIV continue to drop in the world, this trend may be short lived. With next wave of more aggressive and resistant viruses arrived, HIV has a potential to transform itself into a new and different virus every time it infects the cell. Despite the remarkable progress we've made in reversing the epidemic, the truth is that we're just a few viral mutations away from disaster to appreciate the profound way in which HIV transforms itself every time it reproduces. Let's make a genetic comparison. If we look at the D. N. A variation among humans of different races from different continents, the actual D any difference is only 0.1%. If we look at the genetic difference between humans, great apes and rhesus macaques, that number is 7%. In contrast, the genetic difference between HIV subtypes from different patients maybe a CE much as 35% within a person infected with HIV. The genetic difference between an infecting mother virus and subsequent daughter viruses has been shown to be as much as 5%. This is the equivalent of a gorilla giving birth or chimpanzee, then turn around Britain mental baboon, then to any random great shape within its lifetime. Very nearly 100 subtypes of HIV with you subtypes being discovered regularly, HIV in the developed world is almost all of one subtype subtype beef, mostly everything we know and do to treat HIV is based on studies on some type B, even though it only accounts for 12% off the total number of cases of HIV in the world. But because of the profound genetic difference among different subtypes, some subtypes are more likely to become drug resistant or progressive AIDS faster. We discovered that the explosion of HIV cases in the Philippines is judo, a shift from the Western subtype B to a more aggressive Southeast Asian subbed ight, Hee hee hee. We're seeing younger and sicker patients with high rates of drug resistance. Initial encroachment off this subtype is already occurring in developed countries including Australia, Canada and the United States. We may soon see a similar explosion of cases in these countries, and while we think that HIV is done and that the tide has turned for it just like with riel tides, it can come right back. In the early 19 sixties, malaria was on the ropes. A number of cases dropped. People in government stopped paying attention. The result was a deadly resurgence off drug resistant malaria. We need to think of HIV, not us, a single virus that we think we figured out. But as a collection of rapidly evolving and highly unique viruses, each of which can set off the next deadly epidemic. We're incorporating more powerful and new tools to help us deduct the next deadly HIV strain. And this needs to go hand in hand with urgent research on the behavior and proper treatment off non be subtypes. We need to convince our governments in our funding agencies that HIV is not yet done. Over 35,000,000 people have died of HIV. We're on the verge of an AIDS free generation. We need to pay attention. We need to remain vigilant and follow through. Otherwise millions more will die.
